text: it's certainly beneficial since you don't run into dependency conflicts as the number of projects grows

elements.text: it's certainly beneficial since you don't run into dependency conflicts as the number of projects grows

text:
suppose I have a ~/projects directory I'd like to keep my code in, is the best way to do this something like
```::launch repl::
cd("projects")
pkg> generate HelloWorld```
and then add ~/projects to my JULIA_LOAD_PATH so that I can always do using HelloWorld ?

elements.text: suppose I have a ~/projects directory I'd like to keep my code in, is the best way to do this something like

::launch repl::
cd("projects")
pkg> generate HelloWorld
and then add ~/projects to my JULIA_LOAD_PATH so that I can always do using HelloWorld ?
yeah, that's what I do

text: or should I always cd("projects/HelloWorld") and then pkg> activate .

elements.text: or should I always cd("projects/HelloWorld") and then pkg> activate .

text: I wouldn't say it's best practice (that's a very subjective thing), but it's certainly convenient for me

elements.text: I wouldn't say it's best practice (that's a very subjective thing), but it's certainly convenient for me

text: I do activate the project environments as well

elements.text: I do activate the project environments as well

text: the only difference between `generate HelloWorld` and creating the folder + files yourself is the additional `src` folder, which is useful for keeping it organized

elements.text: the only difference between
generate HelloWorld
and creating the folder + files yourself is the additional
src
folder, which is useful for keeping it organized

text: also makes it easy to add tests - just add the directory, create `test/runtests.jl` and you can already do `]test HelloWorld`

elements.text: also makes it easy to add tests - just add the directory, create
test/runtests.jl
and you can already do
]test HelloWorld

text: activate just creates a new environment for that package ?

elements.text: activate just creates a new environment for that package ?

text: and the environment is basically a separate set of paths to look for external packages in?

elements.text: and the environment is basically a separate set of paths to look for external packages in?

text: Im just a little afraid that with the package manager I will accidentally clobber code Ive written

elements.text: Im just a little afraid that with the package manager I will accidentally clobber code Ive written

text: yes, exactly - if you `]activate path/to/HelloWorld` and then `]add MyDependency`, you have an environment specific to that package

elements.text: yes, exactly - if you
]activate path/to/HelloWorld
and then
]add MyDependency
, you have an environment specific to that package

text: if you e.g. zip that whole directory (with Manifest.toml) and send it to a colleague, they'll be able to unzip it, `]instantiate` and they've got the same environment as you had during development

elements.text: if you e.g. zip that whole directory (with Manifest.toml) and send it to a colleague, they'll be able to unzip it,
]instantiate
and they've got the same environment as you had during development

text: why would they not just ]activate it instead?

elements.text: why would they not just ]activate it instead?

text: they'd `]activate` and then `]instantiate` in order to download/install required dependencies for your code

elements.text: they'd
]activate
and then
]instantiate
in order to download/install required dependencies for your code
I see
thanks

text: the Manifest.toml and Project.toml are just markers telling julia what is needed to run the code - it still has to be downloaded

elements.text: the Manifest.toml and Project.toml are just markers telling julia what is needed to run the code - it still has to be downloaded

text: or rather, the dependencies still have to be downloaded

elements.text: or rather, the dependencies still have to be downloaded
